hawaiian_text: ‘O Hō‘ae‘ae ma ‘Ewa ka ‘āina, ma laila lāua i  launa kino ai me ka moe ‘ana iho ā loa‘a ‘o  Nāmakaokapāo‘o. A hāpai ‘o Pōka‘ī iā   Nāmakaokapāo‘o, ho‘i akula ‘o Kauluakaha‘i i kona  ‘āina, noho ihola ‘o Pōka‘ī me kona hāpai, a ma hope, hānau. Ma kēia hānau ‘ana, he ‘ilihune loa ‘o  Pōka‘ī a me kāna keiki ‘o Nāmakaokapāo‘o.
llama4-scout-fireworks_translation: Hō‘ae‘ae was in ‘Ewa, the land where they conceived Nāmakaokapāo‘o through sexual intercourse, and after some time had passed, Pōka‘ī became pregnant with him. Kauluakaha‘i then returned to his land, leaving Pōka‘ī pregnant and alone; later, she gave birth. Upon giving birth, Pōka‘ī and her child, Nāmakaokapāo‘o, were extremely poor.
llama4-scout-fireworks_commentary:
• **Paragraph 2:** This paragraph continues the story from the previous paragraph, providing more details about the circumstances surrounding the conception and birth of Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo'o (the eyes of the pāo'o fish), and the social and economic challenges faced by his mother, Pō-ka-'ī (perhaps ʻnight falls upon the high chief).
• The name 'Hō‘ae‘ae' likely refers to a place in 'Ewa, O‘ahu. 'Ewa was one of the most populated areas in Hawai'i during the 'Ai Kapu era, and it was also an area known for its rich agricultural land. The fact that Pō-ka-'ī and Ka-ulu-a-kaha'i (the inspiration of Kaha'i) conceived a child in 'Ewa suggests that they may have been visiting or residing there temporarily.
• The phrase 'launa kino ai me ka moe 'ana iho' describes the conception of Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo'o through sexual intercourse. This phrase is noteworthy because it provides insight into the cultural attitudes towards sex and reproduction during the 'Ai Kapu era. In Hawaiian culture, sex was not considered a taboo topic, but it was viewed as a sacred act that required respect and responsibility.
• Ka-ulu-a-kaha'i, the father of Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo'o, returns to his land, leaving Pō-ka-'ī pregnant and alone. This event may symbolize the challenges faced by single mothers in Hawaiian society during the 'Ai Kapu era. 
– The departure of Ka-ulu-a-kaha'i may also be seen as a metaphor for the disconnection between the parents and the child's uncertain future.
• The birth of Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo'o is marked by extreme poverty, which is described as 'ilihune loa' (extreme poverty). This phrase highlights the difficulties faced by Pō-ka-'ī and her child, and it may serve as a commentary on the social and economic challenges faced by many families in Hawaiian society during this time period.
– The use of the phrase 'ilihune loa' to describe the poverty of Pō-ka-'ī and Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo'o may also be seen as a way of emphasizing the vulnerability and resilience of the characters.
• Overall, this paragraph provides valuable insights into the cultural and social context of the 'Ai Kapu era, and it sets the stage for the challenges that Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo'o and his mother will face in the story to come. 
– The name Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo'o may be seen as a symbol of the child's connection to his parents and his cultural heritage. The pāo'o fish was a sacred animal in Hawaiian culture, and it was often associated with fertility and abundance. The use of this name may serve as a way of emphasizing the child's connection to the natural world and his role in the continuation of his family's lineage.

reference_translation: Hō‘ae‘ae is the place in ‘Ewa, where the two  met in person and slept together and conceived  Nāmakaokapāo‘o. When Pōka‘ī became pregnant,  Kauluakaha‘i went home to where he came from,  and Pōka‘ī throughout her pregnancy and later gave birth. When she gave birth, Pōka‘ī and her  child, Nāmakaokapāo‘o lived in poverty.
reference_commentary: **Paragraph 2:**• Hō-‘ae‘ae (to make smoothe) in ‘Ewa (error,  misjudgment) is where Kauluakaha‘i (m) and Pōka‘ī  (f) met, slept together, and where Nā-maka-o-ka pāo‘o was born. When Pō-ka-‘ī became pregnant, Ka ulu-a-kaha‘i left and returned to his home in Kahiki papa-ia-lewa. Pō-ka-‘ī was single and destitute when  she gave birth to Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo‘o.
